glosses: Kajaani (a town and municipality of Finland)

words.etymology_text: From the initial part of Swedish Kajaneborg, which is of the same origin as in Swedish Kajanaland (“Kainuu”), probably from Russian каяний (kajanij), каянский (kajanskij) (compare Russian Каянская земля (Kajanskaja zemlja, “Kvenland?”)), which is in some way related to Kainuu and Old Norse kvenir.

words.etymology_text: From German Kajal, from Hindi काजल (kājal).

categories: Finnish terms suffixed with -us (action or event)

examples.english: The day is beginning to dawn already.

glosses: to dawn (to begin to brighten with daylight)

examples.text: Onkohan meillä murtovarkaita? Yläkerrasta kajastaa valoa.
examples.english: I wonder if there are burglars in our house. I see some light upstairs.

raw_glosses: (of faint light) to be barely visible, seem to be, be in sight (at a distance)
glosses: to be barely visible, seem to be, be in sight (at a distance)

examples.english: A bright future is in sight right in front of us.

raw_glosses: (figuratively/usually of something positive) to be imminent, be near, be in sight
glosses: to be imminent, be near, be in sight

categories: Requests for native script for Kamassian terms
Requests for native script for Nganasan terms
words.etymology_text: Proto-Finnic *kaja- + -staa, probably from Proto-Uralic *kaja- (compare Northern Sami guojihit, Erzya каемс (kajems), Eastern Mari кояш (kojaš), Nganasan [script needed] (kou), Kamassian [script needed] (kuja)).

examples.text:
Kajakoin eilen Auttikönkään - mahtavaa!
I kayaked the Auttiköngäs rapid yesterday - awesome!
Suomen tuhannet järvet tarjoavat lähes rajattomat mahdollisuudet kajakoimiselle.
examples.english: The thousands of lakes of Finland offer almost limitless opportunities for kayaking.

raw_glosses: (transitive, intransitive, informal) to kayak (to use a kayak, to travel or race in a kayak; to traverse a body of water by kayak)
glosses: to kayak (to use a kayak, to travel or race in a kayak; to traverse a body of water by kayak)

raw_glosses: (transitive) to sound (to cause to produce a vibrant sound)
glosses: to sound (to cause to produce a vibrant sound)

categories: Finnish terms suffixed with -us (action or event)

raw_glosses: (transitive, phonetics, of voice) to cause to resonate

glosses: third-person singular present indicative of kajentaa

words.etymology_text: From Swedish kajuta or Russian каю́та (kajúta).

raw_glosses: (dialectal, poetic or dated) Synonym of kajahdella

words.etymology_text: Proto-Finnic *kaja + -ta. Possibly akin to kaikua (*kaikudak), or perhaps a borrowing from Proto-Slavic *gajati.

forms.form: Rare. Only used with substantive adjectives.

words.etymology_text: From the same root as kajastaa; kaja- + -o.

glosses: frequentative of kajauttaa (“to sound (cause to produce a vibrant sound)”)

form_of.extra: (“to sound (cause to produce a vibrant sound)”)

examples.english: If you touch her, I'll kill you.

glosses: to touch (+ illative) (to physically disturb; to interfere with, molest, or attempt to harm through contact)
to violate, encroach on, infringe upon (+ illative) (someone's physical inviolability or rights)

synonyms.sense: to touch in order to physically disturb

glosses: from, related or pertaining to Kajaani

forms.form: Rare. Only used with substantive adjectives.

glosses: a person from or living in Kajaani

words.etymology_text: From Proto-Finnic *kajaga, from Proto-Uralic *kaja. Cognates include Estonian kajakas, Veps kajag and Votic kajagõ.

examples.english: When the alarm sounds, take cover!

raw_glosses: (intransitive) to echo, ring out, sound (to produce a vibrant sound)
glosses: to echo, ring out, sound (to produce a vibrant sound)
